journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Intelligent Material Systems and Structures

title-group.article-title: Sensing performance of electrically conductive fabrics and suspension lines for parachute systems

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Massachusetts Lowell, Lowell, MA, USA
2Department of Chemistry, University of Massachusetts Lowell, Lowell, MA, USA
3Warfighter Protection and Aerial Delivery Directorate, US Army Natick Soldier Research, Development, and Engineering Center, Natick, MA, USA
4Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Massachusetts Lowell, Lowell, MA, USA

author-notes.corresp: Christopher Niezrecki, Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Massachusetts Lowell, One University Avenue, Lowell, MA 01854, USA. Email: Christopher_Niezrecki@uml.edu

abstract.p: The electronic sensing capabilities of parachute fabrics and suspension lines coated with conducting polymers, single-walled carbon nanotubes, and their composites are described. A new synthetic method is described to obtain a thin, strongly adhering coating of conducting polymers on commercial parachute fabrics and suspension lines using oligoanilines as an undercoating. The results indicate that both materials have a sensing ability; however, the coated suspension lines show superior performance compared to the coated parachute fabrics.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The performance of a parachute is affected by its lift, drag, and stability. These factors are related to the physical properties of the parachute canopy such as porosity, geometry, and air vent openings. The ability to actively change these physical properties would greatly expand the performance and maneuverability of the parachutes, widen the versatility of the airdrop mission, and enhance the safety of the current parachute systems (Dellicker et al., 2003; McCann et al., 2003; Strong, 2003). In order for the variables of lift and drag to be controlled during flight, an intelligent network of sensors must be instrumented to acquire data throughout the duration of the drop. The relevant data might include strain, load, and aerodynamic pressure. Ideally, adjustments to the parachute geometry or porosity could be made using intelligent actuators based on feedback from strategically placed sensors (Glen and Haggard, 1999, 2000). The sensing technologies could also provide a quantifiable measurement of the maximum strain or tensile load during a drop. This information is important to ensure that the structural integrity of the parachute is not compromised and to assist in understanding the physical dynamics of parachute opening and steady-state flight. From a recent review of smart materials for parachute applications (Favini et al., 2011), electrically conductive fabrics and suspension lines showed potential for sensing applications. The results presented in this article focus on the sensing capabilities of these two materials.

The electrically conductive fabrics examined in this article are parachute fabrics (PIA-C-7020B, type I) that have been coated with conducting soft electronic organic materials, such as single-walled carbon nanotubes (CNTs), hydrochloride-doped polypyrrole (PPY), or polyaniline (PANI). Fabric coated with CNTs and chemical structures of PPY and PANI are shown in Figure 1. The benefit of a coated fabric, as opposed to a sensor that requires attaching or stitching to a fabric, is the strong bond (hydrophobic interactions, H-bonding) between the fabric and the conductive particles. This bond allows the conductive coating to effectively mimic the deformation in the fabric without disturbing its stiffness, flexibility, and intrinsic motion. If the fabric is deformed, the electrically conductive coating is also deformed, causing its electrical conductivity to change. The relationship between the tensile load and strain in the fabric and the electrical resistance of its conductive coating may enable the conductive fabric to be used as an integrated sensor.

caption.p: (a) Chemical structure of PPY, (b) chemical structure of PANI, and (c) electrically conductive, PIA-C-7020B, type I parachute fabric coated with CNTs.
PANI: polyaniline; PPY: polypyrrole; CNT: carbon nanotube.

sec.p: There are many methods to obtain conductive textiles. A straightforward method is to interweave conductive fibers or wires into the weaves of the fabric to form a strain sensor, for example, conductive fibers produced by depositing electrically conducting carbon powder on nylon fibers can be used as modified strain gauges (Gibbs and Asada, 2004). Wires composed of Nitinol shape memory alloy when woven into a parachute fabric can be used as a strain gauge (Lengyel et al.,1999). Textiles with woven conductive wires can measure the strain in the canopy, but they have a low feasibility for implementation because the conductive wires do not completely mimic the behavior of the parachute fabric due to the difference in mechanical flexibility between the wires and the fabric.

A more effective method is to coat or print a conductive film directly on the textile surface, for example, a thermoplastic elastomer/carbon black nanoparticle composite (Cochrane et al., 2007; De Rossi et al., 1999; In het Panhuis et al., 2007; Li et al., 2005; Mattmann et al., 2008; Surwade et al., 2009a; Wu et al., 2005; Zhang et al., 2006). Conductive films are usually a mixture of conductive particles, such as carbon black particles or CNT, and a thermoplastic elastomer. The thermoplastic elastomer film is lightweight and highly flexible, which ensures that the film is compatible with the textile without interfering with its mechanical properties. The film is prepared using a solvent process in which the thermoplastic elastomer is in the form of a liquid or gel. This allows the film to be easily and directly deposited onto the textile (Cochrane et al., 2007). However, the strain–resistance behavior of a nylon parachute fabric coated with a conductive polymer composite is nonlinear in the 0%–15% strain range, and it is unclear whether this is due to the elasticity of the fabric or the conductive polymer composite (Cochrane et al., 2007, 2010). Beyond 15% strain, the resistance response is approximately linear.

Another effective method for obtaining a conductive textile is to coat the textile in conductive solutions, such as PPY, PANI, or CNT. Conductive polymers such as PPY and PANI are widely used due to their high conductivity and environmental stability, nontoxicity, and ease of preparation (Li et al., 2005). The coatings can be applied by simply immersing the textile into a solution containing the conductive polymer, or the coating can be deposited onto the textile using chemical vapor deposition (CVD). However, the authors ran into significant issues when coating PANI or PPY on commercial parachute fabrics using conventional coating methods. In a later section, a new synthetic method to overcome this challenge is described. In previous studies using other textile materials, the results were more promising. For example, the strain–resistance behavior of a plain knitted fabric consisting of 83% Tactel and 17% Lycra coated with PPY showed that the resistance changes nonlinearly with respect to strain (Li et al., 2005). However, the change in resistance is fairly consistent across several stretch and relaxation cycles. The strain–resistance behavior of a wool–nylon–Lycra fabric consisting of 95% wool, 4.5% nylon, and 0.5% Lycra coated with CNT was investigated (In het Panhuis et al., 2007). Repeated loading cycles show significant hysteresis in the resistance of the conductive fabric. Coated conductive textiles have considerable potential for implementation on parachute systems due to their high mechanical flexibility, integrated design, and strain sensitivity. However, the published results do not contain extensive mechanical testing of these conductive textiles. Some of these electrically conductive textiles were created for the purpose of having integrated conductive pathways—not for embedded strain sensors, which would explain the lack of published results of mechanical testing on such conductive textiles.

In this study, we describe the sensing performance of the parachute fabrics and suspension lines coated with five different materials: PANI, PPY, CNT, composite of PANI and CNT, and PPY and CNT using a new synthetic method. All the samples were tested under quasi-static and dynamic loading. The samples coated with PANI and composite of PPY and CNT show a good linear relation between the load and resistance in both warp and weft directions, which makes these fabrics as potential candidates to be used as tensile load or strain sensors.

The electrically conductive parachute suspension lines in this study are suspension lines (PIA-C-5040, type III) that have been coated with PANI, PPY, CNT, PANI/CNT, and PPY/CNT. A suspension line that is coated with CNT is shown in Figure 2. The conductive coatings were only applied to the core yarns of the suspension lines. The conductive coating is bonded to the suspension lines in the same manner as the fabrics. Thus, any deformations in the suspension line cause the electrical conductivity of the conductive coatings to change. The relationship between the tensile load and strain in the suspension line and the electrical resistance of its conductive coating may also enable the conductive suspension line to be used as an integrated sensor. The following sections describe the electrically conductive coatings and provide an evaluation of the sensing performance.

caption.p: Sample of PIA-C-5040, type III parachute suspension line: (a) uncoated and (b) coated inner core yarns with CNT.
CNT: carbon nanotube.

sec.title: Description of electrically conductive coatings
sec.p: Approximately 3- to 5-µm-thick conductive coatings were obtained on parachute fabrics and suspension lines using five different materials: (a) hydrochloride-doped PANI in the emeraldine oxidation state, (b) hydrochloride-doped PPY, (c) CNT composed of microns long, 20–40 nm thick bundles of individual tubes, (d) a composite of PANI and CNT, and (e) a composite of PPY and CNT.

sec.title: PANI coatings
sec.p: Unlike other polymer substrates, commercial parachute fabric and suspension lines could not be coated with PANI using conventional coating techniques such as dip coating or spray coating. It is possible that hydrophobic surface finishes used on parachute fabrics are detrimental to obtaining a uniform and strongly adherent coating. For example, dip coating using a solution of undoped PANI (emeraldine base) in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone results in significant beading and a very patchy and nonuniform coating. The authors have used another method, called in situ adsorption polymerization, to obtain PANI coatings on a variety of substrates, including fabrics. Unlike dip, or spray coating, the fabric itself is used as a template for polymer formation (Hong et al., 2005; Li et al., 2011; Oh et al., 1999; Patil, 2010). For example, the fabric is immersed in a dilute solution of aniline followed by addition of an oxidizing agent like peroxydisulfate (Surwade et al., 2009b). The reaction is initiated preferentially on the fabric surface because of its high surface area. The autocatalytic nature of the reaction enables the polymerization to proceed rapidly along the surface of the substrate resulting in a uniform conducting coating of strongly adherent high-molecular-weight PANI. Typically, the reaction is complete in a few minutes. The reaction scheme is shown in Figure 3(b).

caption.p: Reaction schemes for the synthesis of (a) aniline tetramer and (b) polyaniline.

sec.p: However, when the above method was attempted using parachute fabrics, the coating obtained was very thin and nonuniform (perhaps due to the commercial surface finishes used). The authors developed a novel coating method to overcome this issue using oligoanilines as an undercoat pretreatment. This method called “dimer-seeded coating” uses the dimer of aniline, N-phenyl-p-phenylenediamine, as a template or seed to initiate bulk polymerization of aniline. The authors have shown previously that when N-phenyl-p-phenylenediamine powder is exposed to ammonium peroxydisulfate in dilute aqueous acids, it instantaneously dimerizes to yield a dark green electrically conducting powder of aniline tetramer as shown in Figure 3(a) (Surwade et al., 2009b). It was found that this reaction proceeds just as easily on the surface parachute fabrics and suspension lines. For example, the parachute fabric is first dipped in a dilute solution of N-phenyl-p-phenylenediamine in acetone and dried in air yielding a thin, uniform, transparent coating on the surface. This fabric is then immersed in aqueous acid 1 M HCl containing ~1% N-phenyl-p-phenylenediamine followed by the addition of ammonium peroxydisulfate oxidant. The solution turns green almost instantaneously yielding an emerald green coating of the hydrochloride-doped aniline tetramer on the fabric surface. This is accompanied by precipitation of copious amounts of aniline tetramer powder. The fabric is immersed in aqueous 1 M HCl to remove unreacted dimer and then washed with water and used as a substrate for aniline polymerization. The fabric is immersed in a solution of aniline in aqueous 1 M HCl, and polymerization is initiated on the tetramer-coated fabric by the addition of ammonium peroxydisulfate. This time, the reaction proceeds smoothly on the fabric surface yielding a very uniform and strongly adhering coating of conducting PANI nanofibers that was used for stress–strain–resistance measurements. The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) image shows that the PANI coating is composed entirely of a 40- to 60-nm-diameter nonwoven mesh of nanofibers (Figure 4(b)).

caption.p: SEM images of (a) pristine uncoated parachute fabric, (b) parachute fabric coated with PANI, (c) parachute fabric coated with PPY, and (d) the TEM image of parachute fabric coated with CNT.
SEM: scanning electron microscopy; PANI: polyaniline; PPY: polypyrrole; TEM: transmission electron microscopy; CNT: carbon nanotube.

sec.title: PPY coatings
sec.p: Electrically conducting PPY is synthesized by oxidative chemical polymerization of pyrrole using hydrogen peroxide, ferric chloride, or ammonium peroxydisulfate in aqueous or organic solvents. The reaction scheme using ammonium peroxydisulfate in dilute aqueous acids is shown in Figure 5(a). However, PPY behaves similar to PANI in that very nonuniform coatings are obtained using conventional coating techniques (Oh et al., 2003). In addition, the hydrochloride-doped PPY powder is insoluble and intractable, which also rules out in situ, dip- or spray-coating approaches. The in situ adsorption polymerization mentioned above also yields inhomogeneous, thin, nonuniform coatings. Once again, the aniline dimer–seeded approach was used to overcome this issue. The fabric is first dipped in a dilute solution of N-phenyl-p-phenylenediamine in aqueous acid (aniline dimer/1 M HCl) followed by the addition of ammonium peroxydisulfate. Similar to the reaction previously mentioned, the solution turns emerald green almost instantaneously yielding a coating of the hydrochloride-doped aniline tetramer on the fabric surface. The fabric is removed from the reaction vessel, washed with water and aqueous 1 M HCl, and dipped in a solution of pyrrole in aqueous HCl. Ammonium peroxydisulfate is added to initiate the polymerization of pyrrole on top of the exiting aniline tetramer coating on the fabric. This time, the reaction proceeds smoothly on the fabric surface yielding a black-colored coating of highly conducting PPY that was used for stress–strain–resistance measurements. The SEM image shows that the PPY coating is composed entirely of 70- to 100-nm-diameter globules of nanospheres (Figure 4(c)).

caption.p: (a) The reaction scheme for the synthesis of polypyrrole and (b) the schematic representation for the preparation of the CNT dispersion.
CNT: carbon nanotube.

sec.title: Single-walled CNT coatings
sec.p: An aqueous surfactant-supported dispersion of CNT (microns long, 20–30 nm diameter) is prepared by probe sonicating ~10 mg of CNT bundles in a solution of the nonionic surfactant Triton-X100 in 10 mL of water (Dua et al., 2009; Saran et al., 2004) as shown in Figure 5(b). The parachute fabric is then dipped in a freshly prepared dispersion for ~20 s and dried in air, and the procedure is repeated until a uniform coating is obtained. The fabric is then washed three times in toluene for ~15 s to remove residual Triton-X100, dried in air, and used for stress–strain–resistance measurements. In order to obtain strongly adhering CNT coatings, it is not necessary to synthesize an undercoating of aniline tetramer. An SEM image shows a nonwoven mesh of microns long, 20–40 nm diameter, bundles of CNT consistent with previously published results (Saran et al., 2004), and the TEM) image (Figure 4(d)) shows that individual CNT bundles having a diameter of <20 nm are also present on the fabric surface.

sec.title: Composite single-walled CNT and PANI coatings
sec.p: The parachute fabric coated with CNT described above is used as a substrate to obtain an additional coating of conducting PANI. The in situ adsorption polymerization method described above was used without the need to employ the dimer-seeded approach, that is, even without dimer seeding, a strongly adherent coating of PANI was obtained on the surface of the CNT. The fabric containing a coating of CNT is immersed in a solution of aniline in aqueous 1 M HCl. Ammonium peroxydisulfate is added to initiate the polymerization of aniline on top of the exiting CNT and any uncoated fabric surface. The reaction proceeds smoothly yielding an emerald green coating of conducting PANI that was used for stress–strain–resistance measurements.

sec.title: Composite single-walled CNT and PPY coatings
sec.p: The parachute fabric coated with CNT described above is used as a substrate to obtain an additional coating of conducting PPY. The in situ adsorption polymerization method described above was used without the need to employ the dimer-seeded approach, that is, even without dimer seeding, a strongly adherent coating of PPY was obtained on the surface of the CNT. The fabric containing a coating of CNT is immersed in a solution of pyrrole in aqueous 1 M HCl. Ammonium peroxydisulfate is added to initiate the polymerization of pyrrole on top of the existing CNT and any uncoated fabric surface. The reaction proceeds smoothly yielding a black coating of conducting PPY that was used for stress–strain–resistance measurements.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p: Aniline (99.5+%), N-phenyl-p-phenylenediamine, ammonium peroxydisulfate, and pyrrole were purchased from Sigma–Aldrich (St. Louis, MO). Concentrated HCl (37%), acetonitrile, N-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone (NMP, 99+%), acetone, and Triton-X100 were purchased from Acros Organics, USA. The single-walled CNTs were purchased from Cheaptubes, Inc. (Brattleboro, VT). All chemicals were used without further purification with the exception of aniline, which was distilled twice under vacuum prior to use.

sec.title: Experimental setup
sec.p: This section of the article outlines the equipment used during testing as well as the circuitry used to obtain measurements of resistance from the conductive materials. This section of the article outlines the equipment used during testing as well as the circuitry used to obtain measurements of resistance from the conductive materials.

sec.title: Equipment
sec.p: The tensile testing experimental setup is shown in Figure 6. An Instron (Norwood, MA), testing machine (model 4464) was used to control the displacement and to measure the tensile load in the materials. A 100-N load cell was used for testing parachute fabrics, while a 2-kN load cell was used for testing suspension lines. Pneumatic grips were used to clamp the fabric samples in place (shown in Figure 6(b)). An externally mounted Omega LVDT (model LD620-25) measured the displacement of the Instron cross head. The linear variable differential transformer (LVDT) was powered by a 10 V input signal from a direct current (DC) power supply. A Wheatstone bridge circuit was used to measure the resistance of the conductive fabrics and suspension lines. The bridge circuit was powered by a 5 V input signal from another DC power supply. The Wheatstone bridge circuit is described in further detail in a subsequent section of the article. A computer equipped with LabVIEW and a National Instruments analog-to-digital converter was used to acquire the following signals of data: load cell (tensile load), LVDT (displacement—i.e., strain), Wheatstone bridge voltage output (sensor response), and input voltage from the DC power supply as shown in Figure 7. MATLAB was used to process the data and plot the results. A LabVIEW script automated the displacement of the Instron to ensure uniform displacements for all tensile tests. Furthermore, all wired connections were screwed into a junction plate to reduce movement during testing. Shielded Bayonet Neill–Concelman (BNC) cables were used to reduce cross talk between channels.

caption.p: (a) Instron pneumatic grips for fabrics and (b) split drum grips for suspension lines.
Block diagram of data acquisition system used for obtaining resistance measurements.
LVDT: linear variable differential transformer.

sec.title: Wheatstone bridge circuit
sec.p: A Wheatstone bridge circuit was used to convert the measured resistance of the conductive fabrics and suspension lines to a proportional voltage. The Wheatstone bridge circuit diagram is shown in Figure 8(a).

caption.p: (a) Wheatstone bridge circuit diagram and (b) validation with fixed resistors.

sec.p: A capacitor (0.445 µF) was added to the circuit to act as a low-pass filter to reduce high-frequency noise. The circuit was validated with fixed resistors inserted into the Rgauge position in the bridge (Figure 8(b)). The relationship between voltage output and the measured resistance through the bridge can be described by the following analytical formula
where Vout is the output voltage; Vin is the input voltage; R1, R2, and R3 are fixed resistors; and Rgauge is the measured resistance (eFunda, 2011).

In this case, the measured resistance, Rgauge, is the resistance through the conductive material. The measured voltage output of the Wheatstone bridge was used to calculate the measured resistance of the conductive materials using equation (1). To verify the accuracy of the analytical prediction of the measured sensor resistance, fixed resistors were measured through the Rgauge position in the bridge. The fixed resistors (R1, R2, and R3) within the Wheatstone bridge were changed to match the nominal resistance of the conductive samples to maximize the accuracy of the resistance measurement. Each configuration of the Wheatstone bridge was verified to contain no more than 0.5% error compared to the analytical solution (see equation (1)) within the range of interest.

sec.title: Explanation of warp and weft terminology
sec.p: Nylon parachute fabric is a woven material, which implies that it possesses direction-dependent material properties. The conductive parachute fabric was tested in two different orientations—warp and weft. The terms warp and weft are used to describe the weave pattern in a woven fabric. The warp threads are tensioned during the weaving process and provide most of the structure within the fabric, while the weft threads are woven between the warp threads to fill the gaps, as shown in Figure 9(a). The orientation of the conductive fabric samples as they were cut from a large sample and then tested uniaxially are shown in Figure 9(b). Separate samples were tested for each orientation. It should be noted that the actual stresses and strains in the fabric are two-dimensional due to the complex interactions between the warp and weft fibers within the fabric.

caption.p: (a) SEM image of warp and weft fibers and (b) orientation of the warp and weft samples.
SEM: scanning electron microscopy.

sec.title: Sensing performance of electrically conductive parachute fabrics
sec.p: The following section of the article evaluates the sensing performance of the electrically conductive parachute fabrics. The goal of the tensile tests performed on the conductive fabrics was to determine a basic relationship between the resistance and tensile load or strain. A total of five conductive coatings were tested in the warp and weft orientations. The specimens were prepared with the same physical dimensions of 1 inch width by 6 inches length. The following subsections describe the tensile tests performed on the conductive fabrics and provide a summary of the best-performing samples.

sec.title: Experimental results of failure tests
sec.p: The ultimate tensile strength of each conductive parachute fabric was measured by testing samples of each coating to failure. These tests determined the effect of the conductive coatings on the ultimate strength of the parachute fabric. Multiple samples of each conductive coating were tested for repeatability. The loading profiles of each material in the warp and weft orientations are shown in Figure 10. The ultimate strength of each specimen is listed next to the corresponding loading curve. The ultimate strength and strain of the coated parachute fabrics are reduced relative to the uncoated parachute fabric.

caption.p: Loading profiles of parachute fabrics in the (a) warp and (b) weft orientations.
PANI: polyaniline; PPY: polypyrrole; CNT: carbon nanotube.

sec.p: Table 1 provides a summary of the ultimate strength for each conductive fabric. For coatings with multiple samples tested, the sample with the lowest ultimate strength was listed. The ultimate strength of the parachute fabric is significantly reduced when coated with the conductive coatings. Incorporating CNT with the conductive coatings of PANI and PPY was expected to improve the strength of the fabrics because of the inherent strength of the CNT. The results demonstrate an improvement in ultimate strength by adding CNT to the PPY coating, but not the PANI coating, although the ultimate strength is still less than the uncoated fabric. This suggests that the coating process may have more of an effect on the strength of the fabric than the conductive coatings themselves. For example, the high acidity of the ~1.0 M HCl solution and the harsh oxidant, such as ammonium peroxydisulfate used during the deposition of PANI and PPY coating could have caused hydrolytic damage to the nylon fabric. In the case of CNT, the authors believe the damage could be caused when the fabric is bath sonicated in toluene to remove excess surfactant from the dispersion used. It is believed that both these issues can be resolved in the future, for example, by carrying out the polymerization under near-neutral conditions and by employing greener, softer oxidants like hydrogen peroxide (Surwade et al., 2009a). In the case of CNT, the authors believe a change in solvent from toluene to ethanol or ethylacetate should mitigate loss in ultimate strength during the sonication step.

caption.p: Ultimate strength of each conductive parachute fabric.

fn.p: PANI: polyaniline; PPY: polypyrrole; CNT: carbon nanotube.

sec.title: Experimental results of quasi-static tests
sec.p: The resistance response of each conductive fabric was measured by testing samples of each coating under quasi-static loading conditions. These tests examined the stress–relaxation behavior of the conductive fabrics as well as their ability to monitor changes in tensile load or strain in the parachute fabric. The results of the quasi-static tensile test on the coating of PPY and CNT in the warp and weft orientations are shown in Figure 11. The resistance change is plotted relative to tensile load and strain in the warp and weft orientation, and a unique least-square linear regression line was applied to each of the four subplots. The nominal resistance of the sample is listed in the legend, along with the linear regression coefficient (R2). The resistance measurements from the test provide insight into the behavior of the conductive coating of the parachute fabric. The change in resistance relative to tensile load and strain in the warp orientation could be approximated as a linear relationship. Nonlinear regions exist at low strain and tensile load values, especially in the weft orientation. The nonlinearity in the weft orientation is likely due to the realignment of the weft fibers within the parachute fabric as it is strained axially.

caption.p: Quasi-static tensile test results of parachute fabric coated with PPY and CNT demonstrating the linearity of resistance relative to load and strain in the warp (top 4) and weft (bottom 4) orientations.
PPY: polypyrrole; CNT: carbon nanotube.

sec.p: The subplots on the left side of Figure 11 show the tensile load, strain, and resistance measurements plotted relative to time, while the subplots on the right side show the resistance plotted relative to tensile load and strain. The stress–relaxation behavior of the nylon parachute fabric is evident in the loading profiles when the strain is held at a constant value. Furthermore, the tensile load is almost twice as high in the warp orientation as the weft orientation at the same strain values. The resistance response is highly dependent on the orientation of specimen; the resistance correlation coefficients relative to tensile load and strain are significantly higher in the warp orientation than the weft orientation. There is hysteresis between the strain increments in both orientations. The resistance correlations with tensile load and strain in the warp orientation are the highest of all the conductive coatings. It is to be noted that although the PANI coating shows a consistently high correlation value in the warp direction, this material was not pursued further because of its potential to dedope readily when exposed to water (realistic conditions). For example, unlike other conducting polymers (and CNT), the protons in PANI are highly acidic and are susceptible to deprotonation under high moisture conditions, leading to a steady loss of conductivity. Based on the results of the quasi-static tests as shown in Table 2, the coating of CNTs demonstrates the highest linear regression between resistance and tensile load and strain in the weft orientation.

caption.p: Linear regression coefficients from quasi-static tensile tests performed on conductive parachute fabrics.

fn.p: PANI: polyaniline; PPY: polypyrrole; CNT: carbon nanotube.
The boldfaced entries denote the highest values.

sec.title: Experimental results of dynamic tests
sec.p: The resistance response of each conductive fabric was also measured under dynamic loading conditions. These tests examined the stress–relaxation behavior of the conductive fabrics over a larger number of loading cycles (approximately 360 cycles per test). The results of the dynamic tensile test on the coating of PPY and CNT in the warp and weft orientations are shown in Figure 12 and Table 3. The hysteretic behavior of the nylon fabric is evident in the loading profiles and the resistance response. The tensile load decreases with each cycle. Furthermore, the resistance response does not approach repeatable behavior by the end of the dynamic test. The resistance correlations in both orientations are relatively low compared to the quasi-static results. The dynamic resistance correlations shown in Figure 12 are significantly lower than the quasi-static correlations (Figure 11 and Table 2). The hysteretic behavior in the conductive fabrics is more pronounced in the dynamic test results. The resistance behavior may achieve a normalized relationship with either tensile load or strain when subjected to a higher number of loading cycles.

caption.p: Dynamic tensile test results of parachute fabric coated with PPY and CNT demonstrating the linearity of resistance relative to load and strain in the warp (top 4) and weft (bottom 4) orientations.
PPY: polypyrrole; CNT: carbon nanotube.
Linear regression coefficients from dynamic tensile tests performed on conductive parachute fabrics.

fn.p: PANI: polyaniline; PPY: polypyrrole; CNT: carbon nanotube.
The boldfaced entries denote the highest values.

sec.p: All five samples mentioned above were tested in weft and warp orientations. The fabrics coated with only CNTs show better sensing performance in the weft orientation, that is, linear regression coefficient with respect to load versus resistance in weft orientation under quasi-static condition is 0.756 (Table 2). However, there is a sharp drop in performance in the warp orientation, with R2 = 0.130, which could be attributed to the alignment of CNT in one direction. The overall performance is poor under dynamic testing for all coating except PANI (Table 3). Surprisingly, the PANI coating shows stable linear regression coefficients in both directions (weft and warp) under quasi-static and dynamic testing. PANI has shown the highest linear regression coefficient with respect to load versus resistance in both the weft and warp orientations under dynamic testing. The reason for this behavior may be attributed to the nanofibrillar morphology of PANI as shown in Figure 4(b), the nanofibers are entangled uniformly on the both warp and weft fibers. However, as mentioned earlier, the authors did not pursue this in view of the susceptibility of PANI films to dedoping (loss of conductivity) when exposed to water. It is possible that this issue could be overcome by using self-doped PANI, that is, PANI where the dopant is covalently attached to the polymer backbone, which maintains high conductivity under neutral conditions (Yu et al., 2005).

sec.title: Experimental results of conditioning tests
sec.p: The long-term resistance response of several conductive fabrics was measured under repeated quasi-static and dynamic loading. These conditioning tests examined the resistance behavior of the conductive fabrics over a large number of loading cycles to determine if the resistance response would reach a normalized relationship with either tensile load or strain. The first conditioning test was primarily quasi-static loading cycles, while the second test was primarily dynamic loading cycles. The samples were only tested in the warp orientation. A single sample was used for each conditioning test.

The results of the first conditioning tensile test (3 static + 1 dynamic + 1 static) on the coating of PPY and CNT in the warp orientation are shown in Figure 13. It is apparent that with each successive loading cycle, the resistance continues to increase without returning to the nominal value. The linear regression correlations between resistance and tensile load and strain from the first conditioning tensile test on the coating of PPY and CNT are shown in Figure 13. The first three quasi-static loading cycles show improvements in the resistance correlations with each cycle, but the quasi-static response decreases significantly after the dynamic loading cycle. The results of the second conditioning tensile test (3 dynamic + 1 static + 1 dynamic) on the coating of PPY and CNT in the warp orientation are shown in Figure 14. Similar to the first conditioning test, the resistance continues to increase with each successive loading cycle. The resistance response during the dynamic loading cycles appears to reach a repeatable pattern after the first cycle. The linear regression correlations between resistance and tensile load and strain from the second conditioning tensile test on the coating of PPY and CNT are shown in Figure 14. The resistance correlations improve with each successive loading cycle. The strain–resistance correlation of the quasi-static cycle in test 2 (R2 = 0.893) is higher than any corresponding correlation from the first conditioning test (R2 = 0.824, 0.807, 0.754, and 0.686 in Figure 13), suggesting that subjecting freshly coated fabrics to repeated dynamic loading improves the sensing performance of the fabrics. This is to be contrasted with Figure 13, where sensor performance decreases after subjecting freshly coated fabrics to repeated quasi-static loadings followed by dynamic loading. Additional tests are required to fully understand the role of preconditioning (quasi-static vs. dynamic loading) on sensing performance.

caption.p: Conditioning tensile test 1 results of parachute fabric coated with PPY and CNT (top 2 plots). Resistance dependence on tensile load (middle plots) and resistance dependence on strain (bottom plots) demonstrating the linearity of resistance.
PPY: polypyrrole; CNT: carbon nanotube.

Conditioning tensile test 2 results (3 dynamic + 1 static + 1 dynamic) of parachute fabric coated with PPY and CNT (top 2 plots). Resistance dependence on tensile load (middle plots) and resistance dependence on strain (bottom plots) demonstrating the linearity of resistance.
PPY: polypyrrole; CNT: carbon nanotube.

sec.title: Summary assessment of sensing performance of conductive parachute fabrics
sec.p: The conductive parachute fabrics demonstrated potential to be used as tensile load or strain sensors. There is significant hysteresis in the resistance response of the conductive fabrics, particularly under dynamic loading conditions. The linear regression coefficients were relatively high for the resistance response relative to strain in the warp orientation under quasi-static loading conditions. The complexity of the weave pattern in the parachute fabrics degraded the linearity of the resistance response during uniaxial testing. As the fabric is strained uniaxially, there is complex sheering behavior in the warp and weft fibers within the fabric. Because of the weave pattern in the fabric, the warp fibers are aligned axially and thus demonstrate more linear performance. The weft fibers are woven more loosely between the warp fibers and realign as the fabric is strained axially. This explains why the resistance initially increases when strained in the warp orientation, and the resistance changes nonlinearly for the first 5%–10% strain in the weft orientation. The above results show that under quasi-static conditions, the PANI, PPY, and CNT coatings show high resistance correlation to strain in the warp orientation. Under dynamic conditions, however, hysteresis significantly hinders the effectiveness of the resistance measurements for correlation to either tensile load or strain. For example, PANI shows good correlation between load and change in resistance. However, over time, the sample becomes deprotonated (resistance increases with respect to time) so no further studies were conducted on fabrics coated with PANI. The PPY- and CNT-coated samples exhibited the best resistance to load correlations for a single static test but upon conditioning, that is, testing over extended durations under quasi-static conditions, the fabric’s sensing performance decreased. Surprisingly, conditioning of the fabric under a mix of dynamic, static, and dynamic conditions as opposed to quasi-static conditions, actually improved the sensing performance of the PPY- and CNT-coated fabric. Despite the sensing potential, the fabrication procedure used to obtain conductive coatings reduces the ultimate strength of the parachute fabrics by approximately 15%–30%.

sec.title: Sensing performance of conductive suspension lines
sec.p: The following section of the article evaluates the sensing performance of the electrically conductive parachute suspension lines. The goal of these tensile tests was the same as the conductive fabrics—determine a basic relationship between the resistance and strain or tensile load. A total of five conductive coatings were tested. All tests were performed on PIA-C-5040, type III parachute suspension lines. The results of an extended conditioning tensile test (12 loading cycles including: 3 static + 1 dynamic + 1 static + 1 dynamic + 3 static + 1 dynamic + 1 static + 1 dynamic) on the suspension line coated with PPY and CNT are shown in Figure 15. The resistance follows a consistent pattern of response during the quasi-static and dynamic loading cycles following the 120-min mark.

The linear regression correlations between resistance and tensile load and strain from the conditioning tensile test are shown in Figure 15 for the 12 loading cycles. The linear resistance regressions improve with each successive loading cycle. Although hysteresis still exists in the resistance response, it is moderate compared to the conductive fabrics. The conductive parachute suspension lines show improved sensing potential compared to the conductive parachute fabrics. There is still hysteresis in the resistance response, particularly under dynamic loading conditions, due to the mechanical properties of nylon. Yet, the hysteresis is reduced compared to the resistance behavior observed in conductive fabrics. It is likely that the uniaxial nature of the suspension lines improved the resistance correlations.

caption.p: Conditioning tensile test results of a suspension line coated with PPY and CNT demonstrating the linearity of resistance relative to strain (top 2 plots) for 12 loading cycles. Conditioning tensile test results demonstrating the linearity of resistance as a function of load and strain.
PPY: polypyrrole; CNT: carbon nanotube.

sec.p: Figure 16 also shows the strain–resistance and load–resistance regression coefficients of each coating relative to the loading cycle (for the first 6 of 12). The correlation values increase with each loading cycle through the first three quasi-static cycles (1–3). The correlation values also increase from the first dynamic loading cycle (4) to the second dynamic loading cycle (6). Of the five coatings, the PPY with CNT demonstrate the highest linear correlation values, especially under the dynamic loading cycles (4 and 6). On average, the linear correlation between resistance and strain is stronger than that of resistance and tensile load. Other than the coatings of CNT and PANI with CNT, the coatings performed equally well under quasi-static loading. The ultimate strength of the conductive parachute suspension lines was not measured.

caption.p: Linear regression coefficients of resistance relative to (a) strain and (b) tensile load from conditioning tensile tests performed on the conductive suspension lines.
PANI: polyaniline; PPY: polypyrrole; CNT: carbon nanotube.

sec.p: The smart materials presented in this article demonstrate the ability to correlate mechanical strain and loading with a change in electrical resistance. The authors described a new synthetic method to obtain uniform conducting polymer coatings on commercial parachute fabrics by synthesizing aniline tetramer in situ from aniline dimer as an undercoating. Coated conductive suspension lines exhibited high linear resistance correlations with tensile load and strain, although the correlations of the conductive fabrics are adequate for a low resolution sensor. Hysteresis exists in all measurements of both materials but is prominent when measuring the response under dynamic loading conditions. Despite the sensing potential, the coating method decreases the ultimate strength of the parachute fabrics by approximately 15%–30%. Similar reduction in ultimate strength is expected for the conductive suspension lines, though tests results would be needed for validation. The main advantage of these smart materials is that they are embedded in the parachute materials. It may be possible to develop an integrated sensor network distributed throughout the parachute canopy and along the suspension lines of a parachute system. These sensors could provide useful feedback, such as maximum tensile loads or strains, to ensure that the mechanical integrity of the parachute system was not compromised during an airdrop mission.

ack.p: The authors are grateful for the funding, collaboration, and technical expertise provided by scientist Dr Calvin Lee from NSRDEC. The authors would also like to thank Dr Raymond Dunn for his expertise in testing the parachute cords.
